title: 112_s953
content: The Act titled "Offshore Production and Safety Act of 2011" includes provisions for oil spill response and containment, amending the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to include exploration plans. The Act "Offshore Production and Safety Act of 2011" mandates the inclusion of third-party reviewed response plans in exploration plans for oil spill containment. The Secretary must certify the technological feasibility of proposed methods before approving new exploration plans. The Offshore Production and Safety Act of 2011 requires third-party reviewed response plans in exploration plans for oil spill containment. The Secretary of Energy will use funds to study prevention methodologies and responses to oil spills, convening a task force with private sector representatives. The Offshore Production and Safety Act of 2011 mandates third-party reviewed response plans in exploration plans for oil spill containment. The Secretary of Energy will fund a study on prevention methodologies and responses to oil spills, forming a task force with private sector representatives to assess and recommend improvements for future oil spill prevention and mitigation. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress and other relevant parties within 180 days, detailing the results of a study on preventing and responding to oil spills, including recommended best practices and emergency response drills. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on existing federal capabilities and legal authorities related to oil spill prevention and response. The Comptroller General will assess the response to the Deepwater Horizon incident and submit a report to Congress within 180 days. SEC. 3. CONDUCT OF CERTAIN PROPOSED OIL AND GAS LEASE SALES. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like "Environmental Impact Statement for the 2007-2012 5-Year OCS Plan" and "Multi-Sale Environmental Impact Statement." The Secretary is defined as the Secretary of the Interior. The section also outlines the requirement to conduct certain proposed oil and gas lease sales. The Secretary is required to conduct offshore oil and gas lease sales within specific timeframes after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary must conduct offshore oil and gas lease sales within specified timeframes after the Act is enacted. Lease sales 209, 212, and 222 are scheduled to take place by certain dates. The Secretary is prohibited from leasing any tract that would conflict with military operations. Environmental reviews are required for various lease sales authorized under the Act. The Multi-Sale Environmental Impact Statement fulfills the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. SEC. 4. Approval or denial of drilling permits. Amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires lessees to obtain a permit before drilling a well or modifying the well design. The permit is contingent on meeting critical safety system requirements. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act amendment mandates lessees to obtain a permit for drilling or modifying wells, subject to safety system requirements. The Secretary must approve or deny the permit within 30 days, with possible 15-day extensions upon prior notice to the applicant. The Secretary must provide written notice with specific reasons for any delay in processing a permit application. If an application is denied, the Secretary must also provide the applicant with a written explanation. The Secretary must provide the applicant with written notice explaining the reasons for denying the application and any deficiencies. The applicant must be given an opportunity to address the reasons and remedy the deficiencies. If the Secretary fails to approve or deny the application, certain actions must be taken. If the Secretary does not approve or deny a permit application within 60 days of receiving it, the application will be considered approved. This applies to resubmitted permits for drilling under existing oil and gas leases on the Outer Continental Shelf. The Secretary must issue a final decision on a lease application within 60 days of receiving it. If no decision is made within this timeframe, the application is considered approved. This rule applies to permits for drilling under existing oil and gas leases on the Outer Continental Shelf. The Secretary must issue a final decision on a lease application within 60 days of receiving it, or it is considered approved. For covered applications submitted after the enactment of this Act, the decision must be made within 30 days of receiving the application. SEC. 5. EXTENSION OF CERTAIN OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF LEASES. The term "covered lease" refers to oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico outer Continental Shelf region that were not producing or were suspended as of April 30, 2010, and would expire by December 31, 2011. The Secretary of the Interior will extend the term of oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico outer Continental Shelf region that were not producing or were suspended as of April 30, 2010, and would expire by December 31, 2011, by 1 year. This extension is in addition to any suspensions of operations or production granted by the Minerals Management Service or Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement after May 1, 2010. SEC. 6. JUDICIAL REVIEW OF AGENCY ACTIONS RELATING TO OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF ACTIVITIES IN THE GULF OF MEXICO. Definitions in this section clarify terms like "covered civil action" and "covered energy project," focusing on civil actions related to agency actions affecting energy projects in the Gulf of Mexico. The project excludes lease disputes, sets exclusive venue for civil actions related to energy projects in the Gulf of Mexico, imposes a time limit for filing civil actions, and requires expedited hearing and determination of such actions. In covered civil actions, the court aims to resolve cases quickly. Judicial review presumes administrative findings are correct unless evidence proves otherwise. Prospective relief must be narrowly tailored, minimally invasive, and necessary to correct legal violations. Attorneys' fees are limited in covered civil actions. In covered civil actions, attorneys' fees are limited and parties cannot receive payment from the Federal Government for legal expenses.
